title: Auditory Nerve Involvement: Large Left CPA Tumor
chief_complaint: I have a popping sound in my left ear and intermittent high-pitched ringing. I've also noticed some tingling on the left side of my face and numbness in my left arm and leg.

problem_summary.onset: Popping sound began approximately 2 months prior; facial tingling began several months prior; limb numbness began 2 weeks prior.
problem_summary.course: Progressive, with recent onset of limb numbness.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Intermittent high-pitched tinnitus, mild intermittent facial tingling (left), numbness in left arm and leg.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Initially reported no hearing problems, but upon questioning admitted slight difficulty with the left ear ('not as good as the right').
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Evaluation of auditory and neurologic symptoms.

history.present_illness: Patient referred after evaluation by an outside otolaryngologist. Primary symptom is popping in the left ear (2 months). Also reports intermittent high-pitched tinnitus and neurologic symptoms (facial tingling, limb numbness).
history.otologic_history: No specific prior history mentioned other than current symptoms.
history.prior_management: Evaluated by an outside otolaryngologist; initial speech recognition was excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Essentially normal pure tone thresholds bilaterally.

numeric_results.LE_thresholds: 0-20 dB HL (250-4000 Hz), slight dip at 8000 Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech recognition dropped to 80% for the left ear at this center (was excellent initially). No rollover observed for high intensity testing.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Contralateral acoustic reflexes were absent with stimuli presented to the left ear and normal with presentation to the right ear.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: LE: Wave I clear, but subsequent waves difficult to distinguish/abnormal latencies. RE: Four prominent waves, but Wave V appears absent or markedly diminished (suggesting brainstem compression from the large contralateral tumor).

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: CT scan showed a large mass lesion in the left cerebellopontine angle (CPA). Pathology confirmed schwannoma.

overall_audiologic_summary: This 36-year-old female presents with normal pure tone sensitivity bilaterally but significant retrocochlear signs on the left side. Key findings include reduced speech recognition on the left (80%), absent acoustic reflexes with left ear stimulation, and grossly abnormal ABR results. The ABR indicated abnormalities not only in the affected left ear but also in the non-involved right ear (absent/diminished Wave V), suggesting brainstem compression. Radiologic imaging confirmed a large (4-5 cm) left acoustic schwannoma. The case highlights that large tumors can exist with normal pure tone thresholds and that subtle neurologic symptoms (facial tingling/numbness) are critical indicators of CNS involvement.
counseling_points: Explain that normal hearing on a beep-test (pure tones) does not rule out problems along the hearing nerve.
Discuss the correlation between the facial tingling/numbness and the size of the mass compressing nearby structures.
Review the ABR findings, specifically how the size of the mass is affecting the 'good' ear's test results by pressing on the brainstem.
Referral to neuro-otology/neurosurgery is immediate due to the confirmed large mass.
notes_for_actor: You are a young patient (36) who initially thought your hearing was fine, but realized it wasn't 'as good' on the left when asked.
You are likely more concerned about the numbness in your arm/leg and face than the hearing loss, as the hearing loss is subtle.
Mention the popping sound in the left ear as the first symptom you noticed.
